Title: LETTERS to Mary Eliza Minto, afterwards (1852) wife of Captain Augustus Alexander Ruxton, viz:-. (1) Eleven letters from Elizabeth Barrett, afterwards (1846) wife of Robert Browning; 15 Jan [1839]-[21 Oct. 1856] . The first is a letter from her sister, Henrietta Barrett, and Elizabeth has merely filled in the blank spaces (f. 3b) of the address page. ff. 2-33. (2) Two letters from Sara Coleridge, daughter of Samuel Taylor Coleridge, relating to MSS. of her late brother, Hartley Coleridge; 25 Apr [1849], 25 Feb. 1850 (post-mark). ff. 34, 37. (3) Two letters from Thomas Woolner, sculptor and poet; 5 Apr. 1864, 9 Nov. 1881. ff. 41, 42. (4) Four letters from Christina G[eorgina] Rossetti; [22 Dec. 1881]- 3 May 1882, n.d. ff. 44-49. Paper; ff. 49. Quarto. XIX cent

Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Title: Six Notebooks used by Christina Rossetti for the inscription of fair copies of her poems; 17 June 1856-15 Feb. 1859 and 23 March 1861-11 June 1866. The notebooks are part of a series of seventeen covering the years 1842-1866, of which the others are Ashley MS. 1362 (1842-1845), nine in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, and one in the possession of Mrs Imogene Rossetti Dennis. The six comprised in Ashley MS. 1364 are all indexed, and contain extensive deletions and revisions made in pencil at various times by Christina and William Michael Rossetti when preparing the poems for publication. There are also pencil comments and revisions by Dante Gabriel Rossetti. Ashley Library Catalogue, ix, pp. 109-110
Notes: Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Notebooks by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856-1859, 1861-1866

Title: Songs and instrumental music by Muriel Herbert
Notes: The songs are for voice and piano unless stated otherwise. ff. 1-8. 'Variations in B [flat]' (cover title), or, 'An Old English Suite' (caption title), for piano; 1913. Contains 'Prelude' - 'Allemande' - 'Courante' - 'Sarabande' - 'Bourrée'; ff. 9-12. 'If I had but two little wings', words by Samuel Taylor Coleridge; 1914. Inscription: 'To my dear brother Percy'. Written on the same folded sheets of music paper is an incomplete 'Andante for piano and violin'; [1914?]; ff. 13-16. 'If I had but two little wings', words by Samuel Taylor Coleridge; [1914?]. Another version. Written on the same folded sheets of music paper is 'A Lullaby', words by Wilfrid H Swift; 1914; ff. 17-20. 'Love's Good Morrow', words by Thomas Heywood; 1915. With minor revisions in pencil; ff. 21-22. 'In the Lane', words by Christina Rossetti; 1915; ff. 23-31. 'Three Songs from Song Cycle Love and Nature'; 1915. 'Love's good morrow', 'If I had but two little wings' (with minor revisions in pencil), 'In the Lane'; ff. 32-33. 'The Year's at the Spring', words by Robert Browning; 1915; ff. 34-35. 'The Nightingale has a lyre of gold', words by William E Henley; 1915; ff. 36-37. 'Mirage', words by Christina Rossetti; 1915. With revisions in pencil; ff. 38-39. 'Mirage', words by Christina Rossetti; 1915. Another copy, incorporating revisions; ff. 40-41. 'A White Rose', for contralto voice and piano, words by J Boyle O'Reilly; 1916; ff. 42-43. 'She's somewhere in the sunlight strong', for soprano voice and piano, words by Richard La Gallienne; 1916; ff. 44-45. 'The Daffodil Maid', words by Louie Moore; 1916; ff. 46-47. 'If thou art sleeping maiden', for tenor voice and piano, words by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow; 1916. With sketches in pencil for a song entitled 'Rondel'; 1923; ff. 48-49. 'When Jessie and I went fishing', words by John Bright; 1916; ff. 50-51. 'Since we loved', words by Robert Bridges; 1916. With unrelated pencil sketches; ff. 52-54. 'Song', words by Percy J Herbert; 1916. First words 'Was it so easy to befriend'; ff. 55-56. 'My True Love hath my heart', words by Sir Philip Sidney; 1916; ff. 57-58. 'There be none of Beauty's daughters', words by Lord Byron; 1916; ff. 59-60. Untitled song, first words 'Think not that earth unheeding lies', words by Owen Seaman; 1916. With notation added in pencil in another hand, and the comments of a teacher or reviser; ff. 61-62. 'To Daffodills', words by Robert Herrick; 1916; ff. 63-66. 'The Daffodils', words by William Wordsworth; 1916; ff. 67-70. 'The dawn, from The Duke of Genoa', for tenor voice and piano, words by Cecil Roberts; 1916. Two copies; ff. 71-72. 'A Song of Stars', words by Ethel Clifford; 1916; ff. 73-74. 'We are in Love's Land today', words by Algernon Charles Swinburne; 1916; ff. 75-78. 'She moves, the lady of my love', words by Cecil Roberts; 1916; ff. 79-83. 'Awake my heart to be loved', words by Robert Bridges; 1917; ff. 84-85. 'In Fountain Court', words by Arthur Symons; 1917. With minor revisions in pencil, and a draft of a letter to a unknown singer. Published by Elkin & Co, 1927; ff. 86-87. 'Love's silence', words by Cecil Roberts; 1917; ff. 88-89. 'Heaven hath its crown of stars', words by Gerald Massey; 1917; ff. 90-91. 'O Nanny, wilt thou go with me?', words by Thomas Percy, his poem published in 1758 as 'O Nancy wilt thou go with me'; 1917; ff. 92-94. 'If thou wilt ease thine heart', words by Thomas Beddoes; 1917; ff. 95-96. 'O Mistress Mine', words by William Shakespeare; 1917. With minor revisions in pencil; ff. 97-98. 'How beautiful is night', words by Robert Southey; 1918; ff. 99-106. 'Tewkesbury Road', for tenor voice and piano, words by John Masefield; 1919. Two copies, the first dated 1919 and 1921, the second undated; ff. 107-108. 'Rose kissed me today', words by Austin Dobson; 1919. Published by Paterson, Sons & Co, 1921; ff. 109-110. Sonata for violin and piano in D minor. First movement [1919?]. Violin part only; ff. 111-114. Sonata for violin and piano in D minor. Slow movement. 1919. Score; ff. 115-125. Sonata for violin and piano in D minor. Finale [1919?]. Draft score with revisions pasted in; ff. 126-135. 'Slow movement from violin sonata' [in B flat major]; n.d. Not the same as the slow movement (38.); ff. 136-137. 'Rhapsody in F minor for violin and piano'; 1922, 1924. Score and part. The second half of the score is a draft in pencil. Incomplete; ff. 138-139. 'Légende in E major', for violin [and piano]; 1922. Violin part

Notes: WATTS-DUNTON PAPERS. Vol. III. A collection of signatures of prominent writers, artists, etc, most apparently cut from letters and some with traces of earlier mounts; 1869-1895, n.d. Arranged in rough alphabetical order, mounted on lined paper and annotated with names and dates of birth and death. Preceded (ff. 1-5) by a typescript list of contents. Items described here as 'Notes' or very short letters were removed [by the compiler?] and placed with the 'Main Collection' (now Add. 70627 and 70628 above). ff. ii+251. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Topics: Rossetti, Maria Francesca, author
Notes: Poems by C. G. Rossetti (autograph title on f. 1); 27 April 1842-3 Dec. 1845. Fair copies, circa 1845-1847, in an older hand, stated by William Michael Rossetti to be that of Maria Francesca Rossetti, written in a notebook consisting of thirty two octavo leaves of ruled white wove paper. No watermark. English and Italian. Each poem has the date of composition, and there is an index on ff. 32 and 32b with dates of publication added by Wise. On f. 1b is a note by Christina's mother. For further notebooks used by Christina for fair copies of her poems see 1364 (1)-(6). The six poems on ff. 2, 5b-9, 19b-21b, 23b, 24b-26 were privately printed by G. Polidori, Christina's grandfather, in Verses by Christina G. Rossetti, 1847, pp. 10-12, 17, 22, 23, 28, 29, 39, 40, 49. The poem on f. 23a, 'A Tirsi', appears as the first stanza of 'Amore e Dovere', printed on p. 37 of Verses . The poem on ff. 28-29b was first printed in The Poetical Works, 1904, p. 85, while those on ff. 3, 12b and 18 were first printed in New Poems, 1896, pp. 305-307. Ashley Library Catalogue, ix, p. 109. Octavo; ff. ii+32. Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Maria Francesca Rossetti, author: Poems 1842-1845 by Christina Georgina Rossetti, copied by Maria Francesca Rossetti: circa 1845-1847

Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: 'He and She': a poem by Christina Rossetti; before 1881. Autograph fair copy, written on one side only of an octavo leaf of grey wove ruled paper. No watermark. First printed in A Pageant and Other Poems, 1881, p. 43. Ashley Library Catalogue, iv, pp. 99-100. includes:. f. 1 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'He and She', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: bef. 1881: Autogr. fair copy

Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: C. G. Rossetti Notebooks. 17 June-13 Dec. 1856. The text is written on both sides of thirty eight leaves of ruled blue wove paper, and on one side only of two further leaves (ff. 21, 40). No watermark. There is an index on f. 40b. The principal revisions and additions to the text of the poems are as follows:. (a) Extensive revisions and deletions by Christina in 'The Chiefest among ten thousand', of which stanzas 1, 8 and 15 were first printed in Time Flies, 1885, pp. 79, 80, and 'A fight over the body of Homer', first printed in Poems, 1890, pp. 107-118, as 'The Lowest Room'. ff. 1b-5, 18-28b;. (b) Deletions by W. M. Rossetti in 'Look on this picture and on this' and 'Sir Winter', first printed, the latter as 'Winter', in New Poems, 1896, pp. 103-107 and 112, 113. ff. 5-12b, 35b-36b;. (c) Comments in the hand of D. G. Rossetti, viz.:-'Might be shortened' at the beginning of 'The Chiefest among ten thousand' and 'wont do' opposite the rhyme 'linger/syringa' in the second stanza of 'Till thou return'. The latter poem was first printed as 'Gone Before' in New Poems, pp. 108, 109. ff. 1b, 13. Six pages are missing, viz.:-41, 42 (of which the stub remains, numbered f. 21), containing stanzas 23-28 (as printed) of 'A fight over the body of Homer', and 65-68 (of which the stubs remain, numbered ff. 33, 34), containing a lost poem entitled 'After Sunset', and all but the last two stanzas of 'An Answer'. These stanzas are printed in L. M. Packer, Christina Rossetti, 1963, p. 105, where they are wrongly described as being part of 'After Sunset'. In the original covers, rebacked, and numbered '7' on f. i. Octavo; ff. i+40. includes:. ff. 1, 1b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'A bed of forgetmenots', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 1b-5 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'The Chiefest among Ten Thousand', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy, with revisions; ff. 5-12b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'Look on this picture and on this', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 13-14 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'Till thou return', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 14b-15b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'Now they desire', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 16-17b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'The Hour and the Ghost', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 18-28b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'A Fight over the body of Homer', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 28b-30 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'A Christmas Carol', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 30-30b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'Not yours but you', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 31-32b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'Light Love', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1856: Autogr. fair copy; ff. 33-34 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'After Sunset', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: [1856]: Autogr. fair copy. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Topics: Rossetti, William Michael, author and art critic
Notes: C. G. Rossetti Notebooks. 18 Dec. 1856-29 June 1858. The text is written on both sides of twenty six octavo leaves of ruled white laid paper and of one leaf of cream wove paper (f. 27). No watermark. There is an index on ff. 28, 28b. The principal revisions and additions to the text of the poems are as follows:- (a) Revisions by Christina. ff. 3, 6b, 7, 9b, 10b, 12, 13b;-(b) Marks made by Christina when selecting stanzas from ''Maude Clare'' for printing in Once a Week for 5 Nov. 1859, pp. 381, 382, and reprinting in Goblin Market and Other Poems, 1862, pp. 76-79. ff. 16b-21b;-(c) Notes by W. M . Rossetti. ff. 7, 10b. Several pages are missing, viz.:-17-20 (between ff. 8 and 9), containing ''Out of sight'' (apparently lost, but perhaps ''Bury Hope out of sight'') and ''In the Round Tower at Jhansi'', 25, 26 (of which the stub remains, numbered f. 11), containing part, now lost, of ''A Nightmare'', 33, 34 (between ff. 14 and 15), now Ashley MS. 1365, containing ''An Apple Gathering'', 49-52 (between ff. 21 and 22) containing the end of ''Maude Clare'' and a lost poem ''Jealousy is cruel as the Grave'', and 63, 64, which are replaced by a copy (f. 27) in the hand of W. M. Rossetti. The original folio, now in the Huntington Library, was sold by Rossetti, as appears from part of a letter accompanying it: ''The leaf wh. contains 'Up-hill' (along with the conclusion of 'At Home') comes out of one of these notebooks. It was purchased from me, soon after Christina''s death, by Mr F. H. Evans . . .''. In the original covers, rebacked, and numbered ''8'' on f. i. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: C. G. Rossetti Notebooks. 29 June 1858-15 Feb. 1859. The text is written on both sides of thirty leaves of ruled white laid paper, and on one side only of a further leaf (f. 1b). No watermark. There is an index on f. 32. The principal revisions and additions to the text of the poems are as follows:- (a) Extensive additions and corrections by Christina to ''Today and Tomorrow''. ff. 1b, 2;-(b) Note by Christina, referring to ''Spring'' (printed as ''L. E. L.''), ''Gabriel fitted the double rhymes as printed, with a brotherly request I would use them''. f. 30;-(c) Comment by D. G. Rossetti, referring to ''Sorrow not as those who have no hope'' (printed as ''From House to Home''), ''This is so good it cannot be omitted, but could not something be done to make it less like Palace of Art ''. f. 19;-(d) Correction by D. G. Rossetti. f. 19b;-(e) Erasure, stated by W. M. Rossetti to be by D. G. Rossetti, of two stanzas of ''Yet a little while''. f. 13b;-(f) Notes by W. M. Rossetti made when preparing ''Today and Tomorrow'' and ''Yet a little while'' for printing in New Poems, 1896. ff. 1b, 13b;-(g) Note, signed ''W. M. R.'', ''Notebook 10 (succeeding this one & containing Goblin Market, Passing away etc.) was given by me to Helen''. This presumably refers to the notebook now in the possession of Mrs Imogene Rossetti Dennis. The note has been almost entirely rubbed out. f. 32. Four pages are missing, viz.:- 29-32 (between ff. 15 and 16), containing part of ''Only believe'' and ''The Love of Christ Which passeth knowledge'', and the whole of a poem apparently lost, entitled ''In the Olden Days''. In the original covers, rebacked, and numbered ''9'' (and in pencil ''12'') on f. 1. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: C. G. Rossetti Notebooks. 23 March 1861-24 March 1863. The text is written on both sides of thirty-nine leaves of ruled grey wove paper. No watermark. There is an index on ff. 40, 40b. The principal revisions and additions to the text of the poems are as follows:- (a) Additions and corrections by Christina. ff. 6, 18b-19b, 21b-24, 25b, 26b, 29-30b, 38-39;-(b) Corrections and deletions by Christina throughout 'A Royal Princess'. ff. 7b-17b. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: C. G. Rossetti Notebooks. 24 April 1863-26 Aug. 1864. The text is written on both sides of thirty-nine leaves of ruled cream laid paper. No watermark. There is an index on ff. 40, 40b. The principal revisions and additions to the text of the poems are as follows:- (a) Corrections by Christina. ff. 1, 2b, 3, 5, 13, 13b, 15, 15b, 16b, 17, 20b, 21b, 22b, 23, 25b, 27b, 28, 31, 35b, 37, 39;-(b) Change of title apparently in the hand of D. G. Rossetti. The title suggested was in fact finally used when ''A Return'' (ff. 22-24) was printed in The Prince''s Progress, 1866, pp. 114-119. ''Alas, poor Ghost!'' was printed in ibid, pp. 54-56, as ''The Poor Ghost''. f. 10;-(c) Note ''Begin here'', in the hand of W. M. Rossetti, perhaps written when preparing the fragment for printing in New Poems'', and before realising that the whole poem had appeared in Macmillan''s Magazine for May 1865, p. 48, with the title ''Last Night''. f. 15. The lower part of pp. 27, 28 (f. 14) and the upper part of pp. 31, 32 (f. 16), containing the greater part of ''Somewhere or other'', part of ''Last Night'', and part of ''A Chill'', are missing. In the original covers, repaired, and numbered ''15'' in pencil on f. i. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: C. G. Rossetti Notebooks. 3 Sept. 1864-11 June 1866. The text is written on both sides of thirty-one leaves of ruled cream laid paper, and on one side only of a further leaf (f. 32). No watermark. The principal revisions and additions to the text of the poems are as follows:- (a) Additions and corrections by Christina. ff. 2, 5b, 6b, 7, 8, 9b-12, 13, 13b, 15-16, 17-18, 19b, 20, 25-26b, 27b;-(b) Notes, apparently in Christina's hand, viz.:-'Shilling Mag.' at the beginning of 'Amor Mundi', 'Aubrey de Vere' at the beginning of 'A Dirge', 'Dr Rogers' at the beginning of 'Once for all', and 'Baynes' at the beginning of 'After Communion'. 'Amor Mundi' was printed in The Shilling Magazine, vol. i, 1865, p. 193, and the other notes probably indicate that the poems in question were printed, or were intended to be printed, in one of the anthologies of verse, chiefly religious, edited by Aubrey de Vere, Dr Charles Rogers, and the Rev. R. H. Baynes, editor of the Churchman's Shilling Magazine . ff. 15, 24b, 25, 28b;-(c) Note by Christina 'no name' next to the title 'Husband and Wife'. D. G. Rossetti proposed the title 'Grave-clothes and Baby-clothes' for this poem, but it was printed in A Masque of Poets, 1878, as 'Husband and Wife'. f. 21;-(d) Two notes, the first possibly by, and second by, W. M. Rossetti. ff. 21, 23b. In the original covers, rebacked, and numbered '16' in pencil on f. i. Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: 'Il Rosseggiar dell' Oriente': a sequence of twenty-one poems in Italian by Christina Rossetti; Dec. 1862, Jan. 1863 [1864?], Jan. 1867-Aug. 1868. Autograph fair copies, with a few revisions, written on both sides of twelve leaves of laid paper, and one side only of another (f. 1, the title page), of which ff. 1-6, 9-13 are cream paper, and ff. 7, 8 pale grey. The leaves form bifolia (the leaf following f. 13 is blank). No watermark. For a discussion of the poems see L. M. Packer, Christina Rossetti, 1963, pp. 163-166 and 237-249. The poems, which were not intended by Christina for publication, were first printed after her death by W. M. Rossetti in Christina Rossetti, New Poems, 1896, pp. 272-286. Ashley Library Catalogue, ix, p. 110. Octavo; ff. ii+13. Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ITALIAN: Poems, 'Il Rosseggiar dell' Oriente', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1862-1868: Italian: Autogr. fair copies

Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: 'By Way of Remembrance': a sequence of four sonnets by Christina Rossetti; [Oct.?] 1870. Autograph fair copies, written on both sides of two leaves of cream laid paper. No watermark. For a discussion of the poems see L. M. Packer, Christina Rossetti, 1963, pp. 255-258. The sestet of the fourth sonnet is identical with that of the tenth sonnet in Christina's Monna Innominata sequence. It seems probable that it was originally composed for the latter. First printed in Christina Rossetti, New Poems, 1896, pp. 162-164. Ashley Library Catalogue, ix, p. 110. Octavo; ff. ii+2. Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'By Way of Remembrance', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1870: Autogr. fair copies

Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
Notes: ''Sing Song'': a volume of 121 nursery rhymes by Christina Rossetti; 1869?, 1870. Autograph fair copies, with revisions, written on one side only of one hundred and twenty six octavo leaves of cream laid paper. No watermark. Signed with the address ''56 Euston Square N.W.'' on f. 127. Each rhyme is illustrated in pencil and red crayon by Christina. The majority of the poems are written on reader''s slips for the New English Dictionary, of which W. M. Rossetti was a voluntary sub-editor, but ff. 7, 12-14, 16, 17, 19, 29, 31, 32, 36, 37, 39, 41, 56, 81, 87, 97, 100, 114, 123 and 124 are a different paper. There appear to be three reasons for this. The rhymes are numbered in two series, the earlier, in red crayon, running from 1-108, and the later, in ink written over the crayon, from 1-121. Thirteen rhymes, nos. 11, 12, 14, 17, 27, 29, 33 or 34, 36, 38, 92, 109, 118, and 119, have therefore been added later. On 2 March 1871, moreover, Christina wrote to F. S. Ellis, her publisher, a letter (Add. MS. 41130, ff. 174, 174b) in which she asked him to return twenty-two of the rhymes which were missing. He appears to have been unable to find five of them (nos. 5, 11, 13, 42, 73 in the red numeration) for these have been rewritten on the later paper and renumbered 5, 10, 15, 51, 82. In addition nos. 27, 67, 85 in the red numeration have been rewritten on the later paper and renumbered 33 or 34, 76, 95. First printed in Sing-Song, 1872. Ashley Library Catalogue, ix, p. 111. Octavo; ff. ii+127. Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Nursery rhymes, ''Sing Song'', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1869?, 1870: Autogr. fair copies; illus

Name: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet
All names: Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet, 1830-1894, http://isni.org/isni/N12466 [author] ; Rossetti, Frances Mary Lavinia, née Polidori mother of D G Rossetti [recipient]
Notes: Eleven Valentines written by Christina Rossetti to her mother; 1876-1886. Autograph fair copies written on one side only of eleven octavo leaves of various cream and grey laid papers (ff. 20 and 21 are wove paper). With the exception of ff. 2 and 3 all the leaves form bifolia with another leaf on which Christina has written 'The Queen of Hearts' before folding the bifolium into a triangular shape. Watermarks 'Antique / Parchmen [ sic ] / Notepaper' (ff. 1 and 22), J All[en] / F[ine], dated 1877 (f. 3), and 'Lindsaybyrne & Co', dated 1884 (ff. 16, 17). On the Valentine for 1877 Christina has written 'C. G. for M. F. R.', meaning that she had written it on behalf of Maria Francesca who had died on 24 Nov. 1876. On f. 22b (half of a wrapper originally enclosing the poems, the other half being f. 1) Christina has written in pencil 'These Valentines had their origin from my dearest Mother's remarking that she had never received one-I, her CGR, ever after supplied one on the day; & so far as I recollect it was a surprise every time, she having forgotten all about it in the interim'. First printed in New Poems, 1896, pp. 172-177. Ashley Library Catalogue, ix, pp. 111-112. Octavo; ff. iii+22. Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Frances Mary Lavinia Rossetti, née Polidori; mother of D G Rossetti: Valentines written to her mother from Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1876-1886: Autogr. fair copies

Topics: Cheltnam, Jacintha, née Hunt daughter of J H Leigh Hunt
Notes: Letters from Christina Rossetti to various correspondents; [6?] March 1877-15 [Jan.] 1890. Ashley Library Catalogue, iv, p. 107. As follows:-. 1.Letter to Dante Gabriel Rossetti discussing suggestions made by him on the subject of Christina's poem 'Mirrors of Life and Death', printed in the Athenæum for 17 March 1877; [6?] March 1877. This letter appears to be earlier than that printed in Family Letters of Christina Rossetti, 1908, pp. 66, 67. There is a note to W. T. Watts[-Dunton] from D. G. Rossetti on f. 1. Printed in part in L. M. Packer, Christina Rossetti, 1963, p. 316. ff. 1-2b. 2.Letter to William Bryant, who had pestered Christina with begging letters, informing him that she could help him no longer; 29 n.m [1886-1888?]. Printed in L. M. Packer, The Rossetti-Macmillan Letters, 1963, p. 153. The letter from Christina in Add. MS. 41130, f. 192, is also probably to Bryant. ff. 3-4. 3.Letter to Harry Buxton Forman, declining to sign a petition for a Civil List pension to be granted to Mrs Cheltnam [the daughter of J. H. Leigh Hunt?]; 2 Aug. 1882. ff. 5-6. 4.Letter to A. C. Swinburne, in reply to one from him, enclosing a copy of his A Midsummer Holiday and other Poems, 1884, in which is a poem entitled 'A Ballad of Appeal, to Christina G. Rossetti'; 19 Nov. 1884. Portions of the letter are printed in Christina Rossetti, pp. 21 and 354. ff. 5-8b. 5.Nine letters to W. T. Watts[-Dunton], the second with envelope and enclosing a letter from Mrs C. E. Gringer; 25 Sept. 1877-15 Jan. 1890. Among the subjects of the letters are the health of D. G. Rossetti, and, after his death, the sale of his effects at Christie's and articles written about him by Watts[-Dunton], one Gringer, who attempted to solicit aid from Christina by claiming he had, as she put it, suffered 'hard usage at hands so dear to me', the deaths of her mother and her aunt Charlotte, a sonnet to be printed in the Athenæum ['Resurgam', printed in the number for 28 Jan. 1882, p. 124 ?], and her work 'reading and thinking over part of the New Testament' [printed as The Face of the Deep, 1892]. Letter 8 and part of 9 are printed in Christina Rossetti, pp. 373, 384. ff. 9-26b. Octavo; ff. i+26. includes:. ff. 1-2b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Dante Gabriel Rossetti, poet and painter: Letter to Dante Gabriel Rossetti from Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1877; ff. 3-4 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: William Bryant, poet: Letter to William Bryant from Christina Georgina Rossetti: [1886-1888?]; ff. 5-6 Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Jacintha Cheltnam, née Hunt; daughter of J H Leigh Hunt: Harry Buxton Forman, CB; author: Letter to Harry Buxton Forman from Christina Georgina Rossetti rel. to Jacintha Cheltnam: 1882; ff. 7-8b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Algernon Charles Swinburne, poet: Letter to Algernon Charles Swinburne from Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1884; ff. 9-10, 15-26b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Walter Theodore Watts-Dunton, formerly Watts; critic, novelist and poet: Letters to Walter Theodore Watts-Dunton from Christina Georgina Rossetti: 1877-1890; ff. 12, 13b Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Mrs C. E. Gringer: Letter to Christina Georgina Rossetti from Mrs C. E. Gringer: 1886

Notes: 'Mirrors of Life and Death': a poem by Christina Rossetti; [1881?]. Autograph fair copy, with one revision, (entitled as above), written on one side only of seven quarto leaves of ruled pale blue wove paper. No watermark. The leaves were numbered 1 to 7 by Christina, then 28 to 34 in pencil by another hand, and finally 32 to 38 (in blue crayon) by yet another hand, this last suggesting that the MS. was used as printer's copy. In the top left-hand corner of f. 3 a hand not Christina's has written in pencil 'M. Finlay'. The poem was first printed in the Athenæum for 17 March 1877, and reprinted in A Pageant and other Poems, 1881, pp. 25-31. The text found in this MS. is identical with that printed in A Pageant, and includes the first five lines which are not found in the Athenæum . This suggests a date for the MS. of 1881. For a letter, dated [6?] March 1877, in which Christina discusses the poem with D. G. Rossetti see Ashley MS 1386, ff. 1-2b. Accompanying the MS. is a reproduction of a drawing of Christina by D. G. Rossetti, inscribed to T. J. Wise by W. M. Rossetti, 17 Oct. 1895 (f. ii). Ashley Library Catalogue, iv, p. 102. Quarto; ff. ii+7. Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Poetry ENGLISH: Poem, 'Mirrors of Life and Death', by Christina Georgina Rossetti: [1881?]: Autogr. fair copy. includes:. f. ii Christina Georgina Rossetti, poet: Art. Notes: JOHN IRELAND COLLECTION. Vol. XXVIII. Songs. ff. 55. Largest size 377 x 277mm. 1. ff. 2-3. 'The Vagabond', song; Feb. 1922. Score. Text by John Masefield. Engraver's markings. Published London: Augener, 1922. Proof sheets corrected by the composer are Music Library, H.403.m.(8.). 352 x 262mm. 2. ff. 5-9. 'Santa Chiara' (Palm Sunday, Naples), song; n.d. Score. Text by Arthur Symons. Engraver's markings. Published London: Augener, 1925. Proof sheets corrected by the composer are Music Library, H.403.m.(6.). 375 x 275mm. 3. ff. 11-15. 'When I am dead, my dearest', song; 16 July 1924. Text by Christina Rossetti. Dedicated 'to A.G.M [Arthur G. Miller]'; Cerne Abbas, June 1925' (f. 11b). Scores, in two versions: with piano accompaniment. (ff. 11-12), and with string quartet accompaniment (ff. 14-15). The former version containing engraver's markings was published London: Oxford University Press, 1928. 373 x 275mm. 4. ff. 17-19. 'What art thou thinking of?', song; Sept. 1924. Score. Text by Christina Rossetti. Published in The Land of lost Content and other Songs, London: Galliard, 1975. 377 x 277mm. 5. ff. 20-25. 'Great Things', song; n.d. Score. Text by Thomas Hardy. Composed 1925 and dedicated to Alfred Read. Engraver's markings. Published London: Augener, 1935. Proof sheets corrected by the composer are Music Library, H.403.m.(5.). 350 x 260mm. 6. ff. 28-34. 'Five Poems by Thomas Hardy', for baritone and piano; n.d. Score. Nos. 1 'Beckon to me' and 2 'In my sage Moments I can say' only. No. 2 is imperfect ; both have engraver's markings. Dedicated to the baritone John Goss. Published London: Oxford University Press, 1927. 363 x 263mm. 7. ff. 37-46. Three Songs, song cycle; Feb. 1926. Score. 1. 'Love and Friendship' (text: Emily Brontë); 2. 'Friendship in Misfortune' (text: anon.); 3. 'The one Hope' (text: Dante Gabriel Rossetti). Engraver's markings. Published London: Augener, 1928. No. 1 is dedicated to A. G. M. (i.e. Arthur G. Miller). Proof sheets corrected by the composer are Music Library, H.403.m.(4.). 355 x 260mm. 8. ff. 48-55. 'We'll to the Woods no more', song cycle; 'For AGM February 22 1927'. Score. Text by A. E. Housman. 1. 'We'll to the Woods no more'; 2. 'In Boyhood'; 3. 'Spring will not wait'. Notes: HAKE PAPERS. Vol. VII (ff. 279). 1. ff. 1-253. Correspondence with Dante Gabriel Rossetti; 1869-1878, n.d. The letters on f. 99 (12 May 1871, 22 Jan. 1872) are copies made 29 Nov. 1915, before the originals were sold at Exeter in aid of the Red Cross. Printed, for the most part, from copies in another collection in Letters of Dante Gabriel Rossetti, ed. O. Doughty and J. R. Wahl, 4 vols, 1965, 1967. Includes (ff. 106, 118, 123, 130) drafts of poems by Rossetti. 2. ff. 254-276. Letters of Rossetti's brother, William Michael, [1870?]-1882 (ff. 254-264b), his sisters, Maria Francesca. 14 June 1872 (f. 265), and Christina Georgina, 1873-1886. (ff. 267-272), and his mother, Frances Mary Lavinia, 1 Dec. 1876 (f. 273). Followed (ff. 275, 276) by engraved visiting cards of Mrs Rossetti and her youngest sister, Eliza Harriet Polidori, aft. Oct. 1876. 3. ff. 277-279. Photographs of drawings by D. G. Rossetti of Dr Hake and G. G. Hake, circa 1872, and of a drawing of D. G. Rossetti, n.d. includes:. ff. 1-253 Thomas Gordon Hake, physician and poet; nephew of Lieutenant -General H W Gordon: Correspondence with D. G. Notes: HAKE PAPERS. Vol. X (ff. 271). Correspondence of G. G. Hake and his family. Viz.:-. 1. ff. 1-55. Letters of D. G. Rossetti; circa 1872-1875 . Printed, for the most part, in Letters of Dante Gabriel Rossetti, as with 49467, ff. 1-253, above. Included (f. 33) is a letter of George Price Boyce to Rossetti, 13 Nov. 1874. ff. 1-51. Followed by:- (a) Letter of Christina Rossetti to a brother, probably D. G. Rossetti, aft. 21 Oct. 1876. Imperfect . f. 52;- (b) Two sonnets by D. G. Rossetti, first printed in The Athenaeum, nos. 2431. 30 May 1874, p. 730, and 2496, 28 Aug. 1875, p. 273. Autograph . (i) 'Winter', showing a number of variations from the printed text. f. 53;- (ii) 'La Bella Mano', in Italian (two fair copies) and English . ff. 54, 55. 2. ff. 56-84b. Letters of W. M. Rossetti; 1872-1879. 3. ff. 85-200b. Letters of Christina Rossetti to Hake, 1874-1890, and his wife, Mary Rose Donisthorpe, née Donne, 1884-1894. Includes (f. 163) a letter to Miss Donne, 7 Feb. 1887. Followed (f. 198) by a letter to Mrs Hake from Harriet Read, Christina Rossetti's nurse, enclosing a lock of her hair, 4 Jan. 1895. 4. ff. 202-220b. Letters of Christina Rossetti to Hake's daughter, Ursula Christina Gordon Hake; 1886-aft. 1892. 5. ff. 221-271. General correspondence; 1865-[1893?]. Notes: PALGRAVE PAPERS. Vol. IX. Letters and poems, for the most part extracted from printed books formerly in the collection of Francis Turner Palgrave and given to the British Museum. Contents:-. (1) Letters (about 150), addressed mainly to F. T. Palgrave but including a few to his father, Sir Francis Palgrave, and his daughter, Gwenllian Florence Palgrave; 1831-1923, n.d. Arranged alphabetically. The names of the correspondents, who include eminent churchmen, statesmen, artists. writers and scholars, will be found in the Index to the present Catalogue. The letters of Browning (f. 28), George Cruikshank (f. 46), Longfellow (f. 135) and J. W. Mackail (f. 140), and that from F. T. Palgrave to Alice Ellen Terry (f. 169, copy), are printed by Gwenilian F. Palgrave in Francis Turner Palgrave: his Journals and Memories of his Life, 1899, pp. 94, 79, 160, 255, 261. ff. 1-244b. Henry Irving's letter at f. 115 is in the hand of Bram Stoker and signed by Irving. (2) Poems, hymns, etc, by F. T. Palgrave; 1847-1883, n.d. Partly autograph. A few are printed in Hymns, 1870, and A Lyme Garland, 1874, but the majority appear to be unpublished. ff. 245-277. (3) Five autograph poems of Alfred Tennyson, 1st Baron Tennyson 1884, given by him to Palgrave, 1854-1855, and removed from the latter's copy of the 1894 edition of Tennyson's Works. Two others similarly presented to him by the author were inserted by Palgrave into his copies of Tennyson's Poems (1853) and Enoch Arden (1864) now in the Department of Printed Books (press-marks C.60. k.13, 14). See K. W. Gransden, 'Some Uncatalogued Manuscripts of Tennyson', The Book Collector, iv, 1955, pp. 159-162. As follows:-(a) Maud, §xii ('Birds in the high Hallgarden'). Vv. 4 and 5 are transposed in the MS, which also has 'but sixteen' instead of 'not seventeen' in v. 5. ff. 278-279;-(b) Maud, §xv ('So dark a mind within me dwells'). Several minor differences from the printed text. f. 278 b;-(c) Maud, §xi ('0 let the solid ground'). A draft, with corrections, differing from the printed version. f. 279;-(d) Maud, §xiv ('Maud has a garden of roses'). Imperf, breaking off in the last verse after 1. 5. Two slight differences from the printed text. f. 279b;-. (e) 'Tears, idle tears', from The Princess, including the last three lines of narrative before the lyric. The latter begins originally in this MS. 'Ah foolish tears', but this has been deleted and 'Tears, idle tears' substituted. At f. 280 is a note by Palgrave authenticating the MS. Another autograph of this poem is in Ashley MS. 5111. ff. 281-282. ff. 278-282. (4) Copies of poems of Tennyson, mostly in Palgrave's hand (see The Book Collector, as above), viz.:-(1) Eight poems copied from Poems (1833) and omitted or altered in later editions. ff. 283-290b;-(2) Early version of Maud, §xxiv ('0 that 'twere possible'), as published under the title 'Stanzas' in The Tribute, a collection of poems by various authors edited by the Marquess of Northampton, London, 1837, pp. 244-250. ff. 291- 293b;-(3) Poem, beg. 'June on many a flower reposes', dated at Freshwater, 9 Jan. 1855. Another copy is written on the back end-paper of Palgrave's copy of Poems referred to above (C.60. k. 13), where it is entitled 'Early verses of compliment to Miss Rose Baring' and stated by Palgrave to have been recited to him by Tennyson in 1854. f. 294;-(4) 'Ode sung at the opening of the International Exhibition, 1862'. In the hand of Emily Tennyson, wife of the poet. The MS. includes three additional lines (crossed out) at the end of section four and two other lines inserted into the last verse by Tennyson himself, not found in the printed text. ff. 295- 296b. ff. 283-296. Paper; ff. 296. Large quarto. XIX-XX centt. includes:. f. 2 Sir Henry Wentworth Acland, 1st Baronet; Regius Professor of Medicine at Oxford: Letter to F. T. Notes: CURZON COLLECTION. Vol. CXXI. Works for voice and piano; 1921, 1925, n.d. Some with annotations by a teacher. ff. 22. Largest size 365 x 265mm. 1. ff. 1-4. 'Dreamshadows' (words, Denise Robins); 1921. 2. ff. 5-6v. 'Sing Cuckoo' (words, Katherine Tynan); n.d. Incomplete . 3. ff. 7-8v. 'Under the Wattle' (words, Douglas Sladen); n.d. 4. ff. 9-12v. 'When I am dead, my dearest' (words, Christina Rossetti); 1925. 5. ff. 13-17v. 'When I came last to Ludlow' (words from Housman's A Shrop-shire Lad); n.d. Incomplete . With some practice notes for Intermezzos by Brahms, and Liszt's 'Sonnetto 104 del Petrarca' from the Années de pélerinage. . 6. ff. 18-19. 'When June is come' (words, Robert Bridges); n.d. Incomplete . 7. ff. 20-22v. 'A widow bird' (words, P. B. Shelley); n.d. With sketches of passages for 'Molto leggiero' (see Add. 65083 above). Written on a bifolium with the title-page (f. 20v) headed 'To Clifford Curzon. Sea Surge. A Prelude in C minor for pianoforte. William Alwyn'. Name: Home, F Wyville, author
All names: Blake, William, poet, engraver, artist, 1757-1827 [author] ; Bremner, Isobel, writer, active 916 [author] ; Byron, George Gordon Noel, 6th Baron Byron, poet, 1788-1824 [author] ; Greene, Robert, dramatist and poet, 1558-1592 [author] ; Herrick, Robert, poet, 1591-1674 [author] ; Home, F Wyville, author, active 883 [author] ; Mallarmé, Stéphane, poet, 1842-1898 [author] ; Moore, Thomas, poet, 1779-1852 [author] ; Ravel, Joseph Maurice, composer, 1875-1937 [composer] ; Rossetti, Christina Georgina, poet, 1830-1894, http://isni.org/isni/N12466 [author] ; Sharp, Cecil James, folk music collector, 1859-1924 [adapter] ; Shelley, Percy Bysshe, poet, 1792-1822 [author] ; Suckling, John, Knight, poet, MP for Bramber, 1609-1642 [author] ; Tennyson, Alfred, 1st Baron Tennyson, poet, 1809-1892 [author] ; Williams, John Gerrard, composer, 1888-1947 [composer]
Title: John Gerrard Williams Collection: Vocal Works
Notes: Autograph scores, as follows:. 1. ff.1-6. 'Seven Songs', words, F. Wyville Home; 1911-1912. Dedicated 'To my Mother'. The songs are 'The Morning of Love', begins 'Heart, my heart, what moves within you'; May 1911 (ff. 1v-2r); - 'Serenade', begins 'Now hither, my own heart's lover' (f. 2v); - 'Why bring the old loves back'; June 1911 (ff. 3r-3v); - 'Waiting', begins 'I rise up at day-break'; Sept. 1911 (ff. 4r-4v); - 'Forsaken', begins 'Lie still, forgotten and forsaken'; Feb. 1912 (ff. 4v-5r); - 'The Dewdrop', begins 'Open your leaves'; May 1912 (f. 5v); - 'The Pine-tree', begins 'On a naked peak'; October 1912 (f. 6r); 2. ff. 7-11v. Six Songs. The songs are 'To the Storm-wind', words, Percy Bysshe Shelley, begins 'Rough wind that moanest loud' (f. 7v); - 'Whenas in silks my Julia goes', words, Robert Herrick (f. 8r); - 'When I am dead', words, Christina Rossetti (ff. 8v-9r); - 'A Widow Bird', words, Shelley (f. 9v); - 'I fear thy kisses', words, Shelley (f. 10r); - 'Mary, I believed thee true', words, Sir Thomas Moore, crossed through in pencil (ff. 10v-11r); 3. ff. 12r-13v. 'Ich liebe dich' and 'A Maiden's Song', begins 'Never think of loving'; 4. ff. 14-17. 'March Morning' (words, F. Wyville Home), begins 'All the morning a throstle has sung'; 1916. 2 copies. Dated 14 May, 1916 (f. 14v). Published Novello, 1920; 5. ff. 18-18v. 'Absence' (words, anon); 1916. 2 copies. Dated 2 July 1916 (f. 17v). Published Novello & Co, 1920; 6. ff. 19-20v. 'Three Songs from 'Pot-Pourri' - a cycle by Isobel Scott-Bremner set to music for Voice and Orchestra by John Gerrard'; 1916. The songs are 'Pinks' (f. 19v); 'Lilies of the Valley' (f. 20r); 'Thyme' (f. 20v). Dated July-September 1916; 7. ff. 21-22v. 'Oh Mistress Mine', madrigal for 3 voices. Published W. Paxton & Co, 1922; 8. ff. 23-23v. 'My sweet sweeting', violin obbligato part. Dated Aug. 1924. Song published Oxford University Press, 1925; 9. ff. 24-25. 'A Lament', words, Shelley, begins 'O world! O life!'. For voice and piano. Dated October 1924 (f. 25); 10. ff. 26-27. 'Pretty Nan', ballad for voice and piano; n.d; 11. ff. 28v-29. 'The Crystal Spring', for voice and piano. Tune collected by Cecil J Sharp; n.d; 12. ff. 30-31. 'Sephestia's Song to her Child', words, Robert Greene, begins 'Weep not, my wanton'; n.d. For voice and piano; 13. ff. 32-33. 'Sweet Nymph, come to thy Lover', madrigal for three voices (SAT); n.d. With a sketch of Sephestia's song; 14. ff. 34-35v. 'Two Songs of Sorrow'; n.d. Comprises 'No more - ah! Never more', words, Shelley, for voice with a cello obbligato (ff.34-35); - 'Love's Secret, words, William Blake (f.35v); 15. ff. 36-36v. 'Tu me chamas', words Byron, begins 'You call me still your life'; n.d; 16. ff. 37-37v. 'A Fragment (from Becket)', words, Tennyson, begins 'Babble in bower'; n.d; 17. ff. 38-39v. 'Why so pale?', words Sir John Suckling; n.d; 18. ff. 40-40v. 'Sainte; (Transposed)', begins 'So calm and still'. Music by Maurice Ravel; words by Mallarmé in English translation; n.d; 19. ff. 41-54. Communion Service in C major, for unaccompanied voices (SATB); n.d; 20. ff. 55-73v. Communion Service in G major, for 6-part choir, organ and orchestra, incomplete. With Kyrie adapted from String Suite. Dated 1912, (f. 55)
